modules.name: Artificial Intelligence
modules.description: Questions covering AI concepts, machine learning, and neural networks

modules.name: Further Programming Paradigms
modules.description: Advanced programming concepts including functional programming, concurrency, and design patterns

modules.name: Advanced Algorithms
modules.description: Complex algorithmic problems and data structures

modules.name: Collaborative Web Project
modules.description: Web development, APIs, and collaborative coding practices

questions.question_text: What is the primary goal of supervised learning?

answers.text: To learn patterns from labeled data to make predictions
To explore data without any specific goal

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a type of neural network?
What does the term 'overfitting' refer to in machine learning?

answers.text: When a model performs well on training data but poorly on new data
When a model is too simple and cannot capture patterns
When the dataset is too small

questions.question_text: Which programming paradigm emphasizes immutability and pure functions?
What is a closure in programming?

answers.text: A function that has access to variables from its outer scope
A way to close a program
A method to end a function call

questions.question_text: Which design pattern is used to ensure only one instance of a class exists?
What is the time complexity of a balanced binary search tree operation?
Which algorithm is used to find the shortest path in a graph with non-negative weights?
What does P vs NP problem deal with?

answers.text: Whether P (polynomial time) equals NP (nondeterministic polynomial time)
Whether sorting algorithms can run in linear time
Whether quantum computers are faster than classical computers
Whether parallel algorithms are more efficient

questions.question_text: What does REST stand for in RESTful APIs?
Which HTTP method is typically used to update a resource?
What is CORS in web development?
What machine learning technique is used to model the probability of a binary outcome?
What is the mathematical form of the sigmoid function used in logistic regression?
In the bias-variance tradeoff, what characterizes a model with high bias and low variance?
Which of the following problems does logistic regression solve compared to linear regression for classification?

answers.text: Constrains output to [0,1] for probability interpretation
Eliminates the need for gradient descent

questions.question_text: In logistic regression, what is the term 'logit' referring to?
What probability distribution is used to model binary outcomes in logistic regression?
Which cost function is minimized in logistic regression?
In the gradient descent formula w_{t+1} = w_t - ηf'(w_t), what does η represent?
What is the purpose of adding quadratic terms (x₁², x₂², x₁x₂) in logistic regression?
What regularization technique adds penalty λ||w||₂² to the logistic regression cost function?
For multiclass classification, which activation function generalizes the sigmoid function?
Which of the following is NOT a practical issue discussed for handling imbalanced datasets?
What is the main purpose of data normalization/scaling in logistic regression?

answers.text: To ensure features contribute equally to the model
To convert categorical to numerical data

questions.question_text: What happens when the learning rate in gradient descent is too large?

answers.text: The algorithm may overshoot the minimum and fail to converge
The algorithm converges faster to the optimal solution
The algorithm becomes more robust to noise
The algorithm automatically switches to Newton's method

questions.question_text: In the gradient formula for logistic regression, ∇_w NLL(w) = (1/N)∑(μ_n - y_n)x_n, what does (μ_n - y_n) represent?
Which of the following is a key advantage of logistic regression over polynomial regression for classification?

answers.text: Higher model capacity for complex patterns

questions.question_text: Which machine learning category includes regression as a subfield?
What is the primary goal of regression in machine learning?

answers.text: Learn f(x) to predict y given new x

questions.question_text: Which solution is used for linear regression when there are more data points than dimensions?
What are the three components of a regression problem?
In the search-based approach to linear regression, what evaluation metric is typically minimized?
What is the main advantage of gradient descent over exhaustive search for linear regression?

answers.text: More efficient computation for high-dimensional spaces

questions.question_text: What probabilistic distribution is assumed for the noise in linear regression with Gaussian errors?
What regularization technique adds an L2 penalty to the linear regression cost function?
Which regularization method tends to produce sparse solutions with exactly zero weights?
What is the combined regularization approach that uses both L1 and L2 penalties?
In polynomial regression, what does the function φ(x) represent?
What problem occurs when using very high-degree polynomials for regression?
According to the bias-variance decomposition, what are the three components of expected error?

answers.text: Training Error + Validation Error + Test Error

questions.question_text: What technique involves splitting data into multiple folds for model evaluation?
Which scenario is most likely to lead to overfitting?
What is the purpose of using a validation set in model evaluation?

answers.text: Estimate generalization performance without using test set

questions.question_text: What is the term for a single numerical value in linear algebra?
What is the correct notation for the dot product of two vectors a and b?
A set of vectors is linearly independent if:

answers.text: No vector can be expressed as a linear combination of the others
Vectors are orthogonal to each other

questions.question_text: What operation swaps the rows and columns of a matrix?
For matrix A, the range (or column space) is defined as:

answers.text: The span of the column vectors of A
The set of all vectors orthogonal to A
The set of all vectors x such that Ax = 0
The dimension of the null space of A

questions.question_text: What is the null space of a matrix A?

answers.text: The set of all vectors x such that Ax = 0
The set of all vectors in the range of A
The set of all vectors orthogonal to A
The number of zero eigenvalues of A

questions.question_text: For a matrix A ∈ ℝ^{m×n}, when is it said to be full rank?
In a system of linear equations Ax = b, what describes an overdetermined system?
For an overdetermined system Ax = b (m > n), what method provides an approximate solution?
Which norm is also known as the Euclidean norm for vectors?
What does the 0-norm of a vector count?
Which matrix norm is defined as √(tr(AᵀA)) and is equivalent to treating the matrix as a vector?
For eigenvalue decomposition A = UΛU⁻¹, what do the columns of U represent?
What does SVD (Singular Value Decomposition) generalize that EVD (Eigenvalue Decomposition) cannot handle?
Which of the following is NOT a condition for a matrix to be invertible?
For a symmetric matrix A, what is true about its eigenvalues and eigenvectors?

answers.text: Eigenvalues are real and eigenvectors are orthogonal

questions.question_text: Which of the following best defines probability?

answers.text: Counting favorable outcomes divided by total possible outcomes

questions.question_text: What is the sample space when tossing a fair coin twice?
According to probability axioms, what is the total probability of all possible outcomes?

answers.text: It varies depending on the experiment

questions.question_text: What is the formula for conditional probability P(A|B)?
What is Bayes' Theorem used for?

answers.text: Finding the mean of a distribution

questions.question_text: What is a discrete random variable?

answers.text: A variable that takes countable number of values
A variable that can take any real number
A variable that is always integer

questions.question_text: For continuous random variables, what is P(X = a) for any specific value a?
What does a probability density function (PDF) represent for continuous variables?

answers.text: Weighting function where area under curve gives probability
Cumulative probability up to a point

questions.question_text: What is the expectation (mean) of a discrete random variable X?
Who proposed the Turing Test to evaluate machine intelligence?
What was the first AI program created in 1956?
Who coined the term 'machine learning'?
What is the 'semantic gap' in computer vision?

answers.text: Difference between pixel values and human interpretation
Gap between training and testing accuracy
Difference between supervised and unsupervised learning
Gap between AI and human intelligence

questions.question_text: What is a feature extractor in machine learning?

answers.text: Extracts relevant information from raw data for classification
Selects the best algorithm for a task

questions.question_text: What is the L1 distance between two vectors I₁ and I₂?
In K-Nearest Neighbors, what does the parameter K represent?

answers.text: Number of nearest neighbors to consider
Number of classes in the dataset

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a validation set in machine learning?

answers.text: Tune hyperparameters without touching test set

questions.question_text: What is k-fold cross-validation used for?

answers.text: Robust hyperparameter tuning with less variance
Eliminating the need for test set

questions.question_text: Which learning type uses labeled training data?
What is the main challenge addressed by reinforcement learning?
What is a key characteristic of functional programming languages?

answers.text: Emphasis on mutable state and side effects
Computation as evaluation of mathematical functions with immutability
Use of loops as the primary iteration mechanism
Dynamic typing with implicit type coercion

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a pure functional language?
What does immutability mean in functional languages?

answers.text: Variables can be reassigned multiple times
Variables cannot be changed after initialisation

questions.question_text: Which Haskell keyword is used to define a new algebraic data type?
What is a higher-order function?

answers.text: A function that only works with integers
A function that takes other functions as arguments or returns them
A function defined inside another function
A function that cannot be called recursively

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used in Haskell to handle side effects like I/O?
In Haskell, what does pattern matching allow you to do?

answers.text: Deconstruct data types and bind values to patterns
Change the type of a variable

questions.question_text: What is the result of applying `take 3 [5,4,3,2,1]` in Haskell?
Which built-in Haskell function checks if a list is empty?
What does the `foldl` function do in Haskell?

answers.text: Splits a list into two parts
Reverses the order of a list
Applies a function to accumulate values from a list
Filters elements based on a condition

questions.question_text: How does Haskell handle iteration in the absence of traditional loops?

answers.text: Using recursion and higher-order functions like map and fold

questions.question_text: Which of these is an example of a polymorphic function in Haskell?
What is the purpose of the `case` expression in Haskell?

answers.text: To handle multiple patterns in a single expression

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about Haskell's type system?

answers.text: It is statically typed with compile-time inference
It does not support user-defined types

questions.question_text: What is the correct way to check if an element is in a list using `elem`?
What is the purpose of a type alias such as `type ShopItem = (String, Int)` in Haskell?

answers.text: To create a new algebraic data type with constructors
To rename an existing type to improve code clarity
To define a function that returns a tuple
To import modules from the Prelude

questions.question_text: Which of the following defines an enumerated type in Haskell?

answers.text: data Shape = Circle Float | Rectangle Float Float

questions.question_text: How does Haskell's `Maybe` type help with error handling?

answers.text: It allows functions to return multiple values
It represents optional values, with `Nothing` indicating absence and `Just a` indicating presence
It replaces all need for pattern matching

questions.question_text: What does the `safeDivide` function return when dividing by zero?
In the context of Algebraic Data Types, what is a product type?

answers.text: A type that enumerates a fixed set of values
A type that combines multiple values into a single type, like a tuple or record
A type used only for arithmetic operations
A type that represents recursive data structures

questions.question_text: Which function would you use to apply a function to each element of a list in Haskell?
What is the result of `foldr (+) 0 [1, 2, 3]`?
Which Prelude function concatenates a list of lists into a single list?
In the example `type Picture = [[Char]]`, what does `Picture` represent?

answers.text: A 2D grid of characters where each inner list is a row

questions.question_text: What does the `flipV` function do to a `Picture`?

answers.text: Inverts the colours of each pixel

questions.question_text: Which operator is used for function composition in Haskell?
What is a key advantage of using Algebraic Data Types over tuples?

answers.text: They provide clearer labeling, controlled construction, and better error messages

questions.question_text: In pattern matching, what does the underscore `_` represent?

answers.text: A wildcard that matches any value and ignores it

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct definition of a recursive algebraic data type?

answers.text: data Tree = Leaf Int | Node Tree Tree

questions.question_text: What does the `zipWith` function do?

answers.text: Applies a function pairwise to elements of two lists

questions.question_text: What is a type class in Haskell most similar to in other programming languages?

answers.text: An interface that defines a set of functions

questions.question_text: Which keyword is used to define a type class in Haskell?
What does the `Functor` type class provide in Haskell?

answers.text: A way to compare values for equality
A structure for mapping functions over wrapped values
A mechanism for handling I/O operations
A method for defining recursive data types

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a valid `Functor` instance for `Maybe`?
What is the main purpose of the `Monad` type class?

answers.text: To enable chaining of computations with context, such as side effects or optional values

questions.question_text: What does the bind operator `>>=` do in the context of monads?

answers.text: It returns a value wrapped in a monadic context
It sequences two actions, discarding the result of the first
It chains monadic operations by passing the result of one to the next
It maps a function over a wrapped value

questions.question_text: In the `Maybe` monad, what does `Nothing >>= f` evaluate to?
Which of the following is a superclass of `Ord`?
What is the role of the `return` function in the `Monad` type class?

answers.text: To wrap a pure value into a monadic context
To map a function over a monadic value

questions.question_text: How does Haskell model I/O operations while preserving functional purity?

answers.text: By allowing side effects in special functions
Through the `IO` monad, which threads state between actions
By converting all I/O to pure string manipulations

questions.question_text: What is the result of `[1, 2] >>= (\x -> [x, x*2])`?
Which type class constraint would you use to ensure a function can sum elements of a list?
What does the `do` notation in Haskell desugar to?
In the `IO` monad, what does `return "Hello"` produce?

answers.text: A string printed to the console
An `IO` action that yields the string "Hello" without side effects
A function that takes a world state
An error because `return` is not defined for `IO`

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a common type class in Haskell?
What does it mean for functions to be 'first-class citizens' in Haskell?

answers.text: Functions are always defined before variables
Functions can be assigned to variables, passed as arguments, and returned as results
Functions are evaluated before any other expressions

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a lambda expression in Haskell?
What is the result of `applyTwice (*2) 3` if `applyTwice f x = f (f x)`?
What does the `map` function do in Haskell?

answers.text: Filters a list based on a predicate
Applies a function to each element of a list
Sorts a list in ascending order
Reduces a list to a single value

questions.question_text: What is currying in Haskell?

answers.text: A way to define recursive functions
Transforming a function that takes multiple arguments into a series of single-argument functions
A method for handling errors using Maybe
Using pattern matching to decompose data

questions.question_text: If `addThree :: Int -> Int -> Int -> Int` is defined as `addThree x y z = x + y + z`, what is `addThree 1 2`?

answers.text: An error because too few arguments

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of partial application?

answers.text: To fix a subset of a function's arguments to create a new function
To force strict evaluation of an expression

questions.question_text: What does lazy evaluation mean in Haskell?

answers.text: Expressions are evaluated as soon as they are defined
Expressions are evaluated only when their values are needed
Functions are evaluated from left to right
All arguments are evaluated before a function is called

questions.question_text: What is a thunk in Haskell?

answers.text: A type of algebraic data type
A placeholder for an unevaluated expression

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a potential disadvantage of lazy evaluation?

answers.text: It always uses more CPU time
It can lead to space leaks due to accumulated thunks
It prevents the use of infinite data structures

questions.question_text: What is the result of `take 3 [1..]` in Haskell?
Which function can be used to force strict evaluation and avoid space leaks?
What does the function composition operator `.` do in Haskell?

answers.text: Applies the second function to the result of the first
Creates a tuple of two functions

questions.question_text: In the expression `f x y = if x > 0 then x else y`, if `f 10 (error "msg")` is called, what happens?

answers.text: Only x is evaluated, y is not evaluated
Only y is evaluated, x is not evaluated

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes a higher-order function?

answers.text: A function that returns a boolean
A function that takes another function as an argument or returns a function
A function that only works on lists
A function that is defined recursively
